coded_answer.p: I am writing this letter to you in order to complain forabout the musical show ('Over the Rainbow') that was performed at your theatre last week; concretely on Friday evening.

First of all, I should say that I had read fantastic reviews of it in several newspapers, specially regarding the starring actors' superb performances. These were in perfect agreement with my previous opinion aboutof your company, which is said to be the best exhibitorproducer of musical shows in Europe. With all these considerations in mind, I attended on the referred day to your theatreattended your theatre on the referred day with the aim of having a perfect evening.

However, nothing was further from what really happened. In the beginningTo start with, it was impossible to obtain any of the offered discounts, even though I presented an official ISIC card. Then, the audience had to wait 45 minutes overpast the announced timetabletime of the performance for the show to get started. And finally, when itthey wentcame on, we realised that thereit was not Danny Brook performing, which was really disappointing.
I hope you realise this was totally different from what you advertised, and I look forward to hearing from you in the very near future offering me some money back.

Nowadays we can see a very different world from the one our grandparents, or even our parents, were living in. Actually, whereas they used to talk about how their daily lifelives had changed in comparison with previous generations', we remain astonished, looking at how our lifeslives are changing frenetically. We have hardly assimilated aone piece of new technology when it is replaced or modified by another.

Electronic devices and 'gadgets' make our daily lifelives more comfortable and easier, but does itthat meansmean that we live better than ever? Of course, they have liberated us from a lot of tough routines, giving us the chance to have more free-timefree time.
However, instead of enjoying this fantastic opportunity, people have become hooked on technological advances, feeding back their development in an accelerating, non-stoppingnon-stop race.

Machines do nownow do most of the hard work, but this does not mean that we are working less. People spend more and more time working, searching for new inventions that will make life easier, but then fail to profit from all the obtained benefitsbenefits obtained.
